div.ab:
ἀγαθῇ τύχῃ. ἐπὶ Πύρρου ἄρχοντος ἐν Δελφοῖς,
Ἀθήνησιν δὲ Διονυσίου τοῦ μετὰ Λυκίσκον,
οἵδε ἀπεστάλησαν θεωροὶ ὑπὸ τοῦ δήμου
τοῦ Ἀθηναίων, συμπέμψοντες τὴν Πυθα
ΐδα

Δημαίνετος Δημέου,
Εὔδημος Σαραπίωνος, γόνῳ Γοργίππου,
ανος Γοργίππου,
Χάρης Χάρητος νεώτερος,
Πτολεμαῖος Εὐβούλου,
Εὔβουλος Εὐβούλου, Διονύσιος Εὐβούλου,
Ῥαδάμανθυς Ἀττινοῦ,
Σώστρατος Ἀλεξάνδρου,
Ξένων Φιλάνθου,
Λυσίας Πύρρου.

θεωροὶ ἐκ Τετραπολέων·
Μητρόδωρος Καλλισστράτου,
Δαμόκριτος Δαμοκρίτου,
Ἡνιοχίδης Εὐφιλήτου.
ἐκ Πυρρακιδῶν·
Τιμάναξ Εὐκλέους Φλυεύς

div.p:
For Good Fortune. In the archonship of Pyrrhos at Delphi,
and of Dionysios after Lykiskos(128/7) in Athens,
the following were dispatched as official visitors by the People
of the Athenians to help conduct
the Pythais.1 Uninscribed space
Demainetos son of Demeas
Eudemos son of Sarapion, by birth son of Gorgippos2
-anos son of Gorgippos
Chares son of Chares, the younger3
Ptolemaios son of Euboulos
Euboulos son of Euboulos, Dionysios son of Euboulos
Rhadamanthys son of Attinas
Sostratos son of Alexandros
Xenon son of Philanthes
Lysias son of Pyrrhos.
Uninscribed space

Official visitors from the Tetrapolis:4
Metrodoros son of Kallistratos,
Damokritos son of Damokritos,
Heniochides son of Euphiletos
from Pyrrhakidai:5
Tiranax son of Eukles of PhlyaXIII.

!+1+ This list of the official visitors (theōroi) from the second Pythais at Delphi, which took place in 128/7 BC, was inscribed on a single block in the southern façade of the Athenian Treasury, immediately below the list of official visitors of the first Pythais in 138/7 BC (F.Delphes III 2, 7; on the Hellenistic Pythais and the Treasury, see F.Delphes III 2, 3 and on Attic inscriptions at Delphi, see IG II3 4, 17 with notes). Official visitors were a kind of official envoy sent by city-states for matters relating to ritual affairs: city-states dispatched official visitors to offer sacrifices on their behalf at panhellenic festivals, to announce their own festivals to other communities, and to supervise processions and other rituals abroad – in this case, the Pythais (On theōroi in general, see IG II3 1 1390 with note and I. Rutherford, State Pilgrims and Sacred Observers in Ancient Greece, 2014). In this inscription, there are eleven official visitors from Athens, three from the Marathonian Tetrapolis (see n. 4) and one from the genos of the Pyrrhakidai (see n. 5). In the other three Pythaides, there was one or three archetheōroi ("chief official visitors") who preceded various sub-delegations (F.Delphes III 2, 9 for the third Pythais, and F.Delphes III 2, 10 for the fourth), though this position was not present in the second Pythais. The association of Athenian artists (technitai) also sent an archetheōros and theōroi to supervise musical performance and contests during the second Pythais (F.Delphes III 2, 47-49), who were independent of the official visitors dispatched by the city of Athens (see S. Aneziri, Die Vereine der dionysischen Techniten, 2003, 140-41 and 155-58, and IG II2 1320 with notes on the artists generally).
In col. 1, the first five lines were inscribed with slightly larger letters and thicker strokes. Having only three letters, line 5, together with an uninscribed space beneath, serves as a visual break between the preamble (ll. 1-5) and the list of names (ll. 6-15), inscribed with slightly smaller letters. Col. 2 was inscribed to the right of col. 1, with its first line standing between ll. 2-3 of col. 1, and below col. 2 of F.Delphes III 2, 7 (138/7 BC), which contains a list of official visitors from the Marathonic Tetrapolis that was added later. Since there is uninscribed space on the block below col. 1, the layout seems to have been deliberately arranged to place the list of official visitors from the Tetrapolis directly below the one in F.Delphes III 2, 7. [After having consulted the squeezes of F.Delphes III 2, 8 among others, I argue that col. 1, ll. 6-15 of F.Delphes III 2, 8 should be attributed to the stonecutter of F.Delphes III 2, 12 (given their constant usage of non-rounded Φ, Π with uneven legs, and more rounded Ω), and am skeptical of Tracy identification of the lettercutters of the first two Pythaides – WBB].!

!+2+ For this formula indicating the natural father, see AIUK 4.5 (BM dedications), p. 59. This Eudemos reappears in the list of cavalry (F.Delphes III 2, 27, col. 2, l. 14, as does Rhadamanthys, col. 2, l. 28, see the note there), and may belong to the family of Sarapion of Melite, which would appear frequently in the third and fourth Pythaides. Such family connections between participants in the Pythais (theōroi, Pythaists, ephebes) are common, and they indicate an growing elitism in Athenian public activities in the second half of the second century onwards: on this see K. Karila-Cohen in J.-Ch. Couvenhes and S. Milanezi eds., Individus, groupes et politique à Athènes de Solon à Mithridate, 2007, 365-384. The !

!+3+ The term "the younger" (neoteros) distinguished this Chares (II) from his homonymous father Chares (I); his son Chares (III) also participated in this Pythais as ephebe (F.Delphes III 2, 24, col. 1, l. 19). This distinguisher was not used consistently. In Athenian name lists, it is usually abbreviated to ne (e.g., IG II2 1335, ll. 19 and 35, together with the abbreviated "the elder", ll. 21 and 43), here it was written out in full.!

!+4+ The Tetrapolis was an association of four Attic demes: Marathon, Probalinthos, Trikorynthos and Oinoe (see AIO 2618 with notes). The community maintained a special connection with Delphi independently from Athens, even when the sanctuary of Apollo was under Aitolian control: Delphi honoured Tetrapolis because of their ‘proximity with the god’ and granted them both priority access to the oracle (promanteia) and the right to sacrifice at the altars immediately after the Delphians, in F.Delphes III 2, 18 (mid-third century BC), F.Delphes III 2, 19 (late third century decree, re-inscribed in the second century BC), and F.Delphes III 2, 20 (178/7 BC), three decrees inscribed on the same anta on the east face of the Treasury, as well as the fragmentary F.Delphes III 2, 21 (third century). Theōroi from the Tetrapolis also appear in F.Delphes III 2, 7 from the first Pythais (138/7 BC). One Pythaist from the Tetrapolis is known from the third Pythais (F.Delphes III 2, 13, 106/5 BC). In the fourth Pythais (97/6 BC), the Tetrapolis had one archetheōros, three theōroi and one Pythaist (F.Delphes III 2, 10). On the Tetrapolis' relationship with Delphi, see K. Karila-Cohen in M.-F. Baslez and F. Prevot eds., Prosopographie et histoire religieuse, 2005, 76–80. The sixth letter of the word ‘Tetrapolis’ is carved with a three-legged pi, rather than the regular two-legged pi (Π), probably a mistake by the lettercutter.!

!+5+ The Pyrrhakidai were an Athenian genos, perhaps emerging in the late second century BC, although two inscriptions dated to ca. 400 BC on Delos record two names as ‘of Pyrrhakidai’ (I Délos 66 and 67), which might indicate an earlier connection to Delos. The Pyrrhakidai sent an Eukles son of Timanax as theoros for the first Pythais (F.Delphes III 2, 7), who must be a relative (father?) of the Timanax appearing here. Later, in the third Pythais one Pythaist comes from the Pyrrhakidai (F.Delphes III 2, 13, col. 1), and in the fourth Pythais three Pythaists came from the Pyrrhakidai, two of whom were also relatives of Timanax (F.Delphes III 2, 10, col. 2). As this family of Timanax appears to be much involved in the Pythaides, they may have played a special role in the Pythais, perhaps related to their connection with Delos. On the Pyrrhakidai in general, see Agora XIX P5 with notes, N. Papazarkadas, Sacred and Public Land, 2012, Appendix V; and S. Humphreys, Kinship in Ancient Athens, 2018, 680, 716.!
